_basics.name: Yunsik Kim
_basics._summary: A German-born theoretical physicist, widely ranked among the greatest and most influential scientists of all time

education.institution: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
education.area: Department of Earth, Environmental and Geographical Sciences

education.studyType: Bachelor of Arts in Geography Education

experience.name: Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton University
experience.summary: Teaching at Palmer Physical Laboratory (now 302 Frist Campus Center). While not a professor at Princeton, I associated with the physics professors and continued to give lectures on campus.

_volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

_publications.name: Investigating quantitatively the root causes of non-implementation of public surveying performance review and deriving institutional improvement measures

Extracting urban areas of interest using HDBSCAN clustering method
_publications.publisher: Journal of the Korean Cartographic Association

_publications.name: Measuring traffic congestion with novel metrics: A case study of six U.S. metropolitan areas

_awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
_awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

_projects.name: Quantum Computing
_projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
